content: The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, citing the actions of those involved in the Civil Rights movement from the 1950s to the 1960s as examples. The Act highlights events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, drive for voting rights in Mississippi, and March to Selma, emphasizing the contributions of lesser-known figures alongside prominent leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and Rosa Parks. The importance of collecting oral histories from individuals in the Civil Rights movement is emphasized to preserve their first-hand memories and provide a detailed history for future generations. A coordinated Federal project is proposed to gather primary-source, eyewitness material and highlight the lesser-known figures who played crucial roles in the movement. The importance of collecting oral histories from individuals in the Civil Rights movement is emphasized to preserve their first-hand memories. A coordinated Federal project is proposed to gather primary-source material and highlight the efforts of public and private entities in documenting the movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are suggested as appropriate repositories for these oral histories. The Act aims to establish a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals involved in the American Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and Smithsonian will manage this project to preserve the memories of these individuals for future generations. The Act establishes a joint project at the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights Movement. The project aims to preserve the memories of these individuals for future generations. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to survey and collect audio and video recordings of Civil Rights movement participants' reminiscences, personal histories, and relevant materials. The Secretary will establish an oral history project to collect recordings and materials related to the personal histories of Civil Rights movement participants. The collection will be made available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Director of the museum will oversee the implementation of this project. The Secretary will carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture. Agreements with other entities and consultation with interested persons will be used to solicit, acquire, and make recordings available under the project. Services of experts and consultants will be utilized in carrying out project activities. The Librarian and the Secretary will develop guidelines for acquiring recordings under the project. They may procure services, accept volunteer help, and make advance payments. They will start collecting video recordings soon after the enactment of the Act. The Librarian and the Secretary will collect video and audio recordings related to the Civil Rights movement, focusing on the period 1954 through 1968. They are encouraged to solicit donations for the project. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary are encouraged to solicit donations to support activities related to the Civil Rights movement. Any funds donated for this purpose will be deposited into a dedicated account and used solely to support these activities. The Librarian of Congress may not deposit funds donated for supporting Civil Rights activities into any account other than the dedicated one. Authorization of appropriations includes $500,000 for fiscal year 2010 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2011 through 2014.
